columns.text: The goal of this task is to explain if it is advantageous for a company to lease equipment when it requires a security deposit.

***What is a security deposit?***

When a lease is being considered, an initial security deposit is often required to guarantee the lessee's intent to proceed with the lease. This is why the term security deposit is used! It is an implementation of assuring that the lease will be executed.  

The security deposit can be used to support damaged or unplanned wear and tear, mostly associated with misuse or other human causes.

A common practice is that the deposit is returned to the lessor at the expiration of the lease. In this task, we use this hypothesis for our solution.

***What is the effect of the security payment on the cash flow of a lease?***

The security payment has to be registered as a ***cost*** when this is indicated ( in this case at the inception of the lease) and, if no reasons appear during the use to be retained by the lessor, is registered as in income at the end of the lease, since it is returned to the lessee. 

Two main effects are: 
- The reduction of savings of buying the equipment since the lessee now saves 
$$\$7,300,000 - \$600,000 = \$6,700,000$$ 
We deduct from the savings the cost of the security deposit. 

- The Increase of the cash flow in the last year, since at the end of life the lessee should receive the entire amount of the security deposit.

Therefore, to the cash flow created in the previous task. ***we just add the value of the security payment as a cost at the moment of the beginning, and as an income at the end***. Let's see how it results in Figure 1.

Figure 1. Cash flow of leasing with security payment at the beginning.

To calculate the $\operatorname{NPV}$ we apply the function **NPV** in our spreadsheet as shown in figure 2:

Figure 2. Net Advantage to Leasing calculation.

The $\operatorname{NPV}$ value after considering the security payment is $\$500,433$. As been said before this $\operatorname{NPV}$ represents the Net Advantage to Leasing. ***The result is positive so leasing is still a very attractive option over buying***.
